title: 1989–90 in English football
text:
The 1989–90 season was the 110th season of competitive <a href="football%20%28soccer%29">football</a> in England.
Overview.
English clubs were still banned from competing in European competitions following the <a href="Heysel%20Stadium%20disaster">Heysel Stadium disaster</a>.
The season marked the beginning of the regular trend for clubs to leave their homes of many years and head for purpose built new stadia, following the bold move to <a href="Glanford%20Park">Glanford Park</a> by <a href="Scunthorpe%20United%20F.C.">Scunthorpe United</a> in 1988. <a href="Walsall%20F.C.">Walsall</a> and <a href="Chester%20City%20F.C.">Chester City</a> brought the curtain down on their many years at <a href="Fellows%20Park">Fellows Park</a> and <a href="Sealand%20Road">Sealand Road</a> respectively (both with games against <a href="Rotherham%20United%20F.C.">Rotherham United</a>). Walsall moved to the <a href="Bescot%20Stadium">Bescot Stadium</a>, while Chester began a groundshare with <a href="Macclesfield%20Town%20F.C.">Macclesfield Town</a> at <a href="Moss%20Rose">Moss Rose</a> until their <a href="Deva%20Stadium">new stadium</a> was completed.
Meanwhile, <a href="Football%20Conference">Football Conference</a> sides <a href="Wycombe%20Wanderers%20F.C.">Wycombe Wanderers</a> and <a href="Yeovil%20Town%20F.C.">Yeovil Town</a> relocated to <a href="Adams%20Park">Adams Park</a> and <a href="Huish%20Park">Huish Park</a> respectively.
Diary of the season.
1 July 1989 – Midfielder <a href="Mike%20Phelan">Mike Phelan</a> joins <a href="Manchester%20United%20F.C.">Manchester United</a> in a £750,000 transfer from <a href="Norwich%20City%20F.C.">Norwich City</a>.
5 July 1989 – <a href="Lou%20Macari">Lou Macari</a> departs from <a href="Swindon%20Town%20F.C.">Swindon Town</a> to succeed <a href="John%20Lyall">John Lyall</a> as manager of <a href="West%20Ham%20United%20F.C.">West Ham United</a>. He is only the sixth manager to have taken charge of West Ham since their formation in 1900.
6 July 1989 – After just four months at <a href="Rangers%20F.C.">Glasgow Rangers</a>, <a href="Mel%20Sterland">Mel Sterland</a> leaves the Scottish league champions and returns to England in a move to Second Division <a href="Leeds%20United%20F.C.">Leeds United</a> for £600,000.
8 July 1989 – <a href="Olympique%20Marseille">Olympique Marseille</a> pay <a href="Tottenham%20Hotspur%20F.C.">Tottenham Hotspur</a> £4.5 million for winger <a href="Chris%20Waddle">Chris Waddle</a>, a fee that makes him the most expensive British player. After a year in France with <a href="Bordeaux">Bordeaux</a>, <a href="Clive%20Allen">Clive Allen</a> returns to England in a £1million move to newly promoted <a href="Manchester%20City%20F.C.">Manchester City</a>.
10 July 1989 – Scottish striker <a href="Mark%20McGhee">Mark McGhee</a> returns to <a href="Newcastle%20United%20F.C.">Newcastle United</a> on a free transfer from <a href="Scottish%20Cup">Scottish Cup</a> winners <a href="Celtic%20F.C.">Celtic</a>.
11 July 1989 – <a href="Aston%20Villa%20F.C.">Aston Villa</a> sign <a href="Kent%20Nielsen">Kent Nielsen</a>, the <a href="Denmark%20national%20football%20team">Denmark</a> central defender, from <a href="Br%C3%B8ndby">Brøndby</a> in a £500,000 deal.
12 July 1989 – <a href="Glenn%20Hysen">Glenn Hysen</a>, the Swedish defender who had been expected to sign for Manchester United, is instead signed by <a href="Liverpool%20F.C.">Liverpool</a>. <a href="Don%20Howe">Don Howe</a>, a member of the English coaching staff, resigns as assistant manager of <a href="Wimbledon%20F.C.">Wimbledon</a> and becomes assistant to <a href="Trevor%20Francis">Trevor Francis</a> at <a href="Queens%20Park%20Rangers%20F.C.">Queens Park Rangers</a>.
13 July 1989 – Third Division <a href="Notts%20County%20F.C.">Notts County</a> reject a £750,000 bid for 22–year–old defender <a href="Dean%20Yates">Dean Yates</a>.
15 July 1989 – <a href="Laurie%20Cunningham">Laurie Cunningham</a>, who played in Wimbledon's <a href="1988%20FA%20Cup%20Final">FA Cup triumph</a> 14 months ago and had a successful spell with <a href="West%20Bromwich%20Albion%20F.C.">West Bromwich Albion</a> in the late 1970s, dies in a car crash in Spain. He was 33 years old and had been playing for <a href="Rayo%20Vallecano">Rayo Vallecano</a> at the time of his death.
17 July 1989 – Liverpool sign 18–year–old defender <a href="Steve%20Harkness">Steve Harkness</a> from <a href="Carlisle%20United%20F.C.">Carlisle United</a> for £75,000. Tottenham Hotspur sign midfielder <a href="Steve%20Sedgley">Steve Sedgley</a> from <a href="Coventry%20City%20F.C.">Coventry City</a> for £750,000.
19 July 1989 – Former Tottenham Hotspur midfielder <a href="Ossie%20Ardiles">Ossie Ardiles</a>, 37 next month, is appointed player–manager of Swindon Town.
21 July 1989 – A tribunal orders Manchester United to pay £1.5 million to <a href="Nottingham%20Forest%20F.C.">Nottingham Forest</a> for 26–year–old midfielder <a href="Neil%20Webb">Neil Webb</a>.
24 July 1989 – Aston Villa sign Manchester United defender <a href="Paul%20McGrath%20%28footballer%29">Paul McGrath</a> for £400,000.
26 July 1989 – <a href="Norman%20Whiteside">Norman Whiteside</a> moves from Manchester United to <a href="Everton%20F.C.">Everton</a> for £750,000.
27 July 1989 – Everton pay <a href="Leicester%20City%20F.C.">Leicester City</a> £1.1 million for striker <a href="Mike%20Newell%20%28footballer%29">Mike Newell</a>.
28 July 1989 – <a href="Maidstone%20United%20F.C.%20%281897%29">Maidstone United</a> prepare for their first <a href="Football%20League">Football League</a> season with a £10,000 move for 19–year–old <a href="Leytonstone%20F.C.">Leytonstone</a> defender <a href="Warren%20Barton">Warren Barton</a>.
31 July 1989 – Norwich City pay Coventry City £525,000 for Welsh winger <a href="David%20Phillips%20%28Welsh%20footballer%29">David Phillips</a>.
3 August 1989 – Nottingham Forest pay Leeds United £650,000 for <a href="Republic%20of%20Ireland%20national%20football%20team">Republic of Ireland</a> midfielder <a href="John%20Sheridan%20%28footballer%29">John Sheridan</a>.
7 August 1989 – Everton sign Aston Villa defender <a href="Martin%20Keown">Martin Keown</a> for £750,000.
12 August 1989 - <a href="Liverpool%20F.C.">Liverpool</a> beat <a href="Arsenal%20F.C.">Arsenal</a> 1-0 in the <a href="1989%20FA%20Charity%20Shield">Charity Shield</a> at Wembley. <a href="Peter%20Beardsley">Peter Beardsley</a> scores the only goal of the game.
14 August 1989 – <a href="Adrian%20Heath">Adrian Heath</a> returns to English football after less than a year in Spain when he joins Aston Villa from <a href="Espanyol">Espanyol</a> for £360,000.
18 August 1989 – Property tycoon <a href="Michael%20Knighton">Michael Knighton</a> agrees to buy control of Manchester United in a deal which is believed to be worth around £20 million.
19 August 1989 – On the first day of the <a href="Football%20League%20First%20Division">First Division</a> season, champions Arsenal lose 4–1 away to Manchester United, while Liverpool beat <a href="Manchester%20City%20F.C.">Manchester City</a> 3–1. Second Division promotion favourites Newcastle United and Leeds United clash at <a href="St%20James%27%20Park">St James' Park</a> in a match which ends with the home side winning 5–2, with <a href="Micky%20Quinn">Micky Quinn</a> scoring four goals on his Newcastle debut. In the Second Division, <a href="Frank%20McAvennie">Frank McAvennie</a> breaks his leg in West Ham's 1-1 draw at <a href="Stoke%20City%20F.C.">Stoke</a> and is expected to be out of action until at least the winter.
21 August 1989 – <a href="Luton%20Town%20F.C.">Luton Town</a> pay a club record £650,000 for striker <a href="Lars%20Elstrup">Lars Elstrup</a> from Danish side <a href="OB%20Odense">OB Odense</a>.
22 August 1989 – Tottenham Hotspur sign defender <a href="Pat%20van%20den%20Hauwe">Pat van den Hauwe</a> from Everton for £650,000.
23 August 1989 – <a href="Paul%20Bracewell">Paul Bracewell</a>, who has missed most of the last three years because of injury, joins <a href="Sunderland%20A.F.C.">Sunderland</a> for £250,000.
24 August 1989 – West Ham United boost their Second Division promotion push with a £675,000 move for Queens Park Rangers midfielder <a href="Martin%20Allen">Martin Allen</a>, just weeks after a move to First Division champions Arsenal collapsed.
26 August 1989 - Newly promoted Chelsea go top of the First Division after three games with a 4-0 home win over Sheffield Wednesday. Derby County beat Manchester United 2-0 at the Baseball Ground. A thrilling Second Division encounter at <a href="Dean%20Court">Dean Court</a> sees <a href="AFC%20Bournemouth">AFC Bournemouth</a> beat <a href="Hull%20City%20A.F.C.">Hull City</a> 5-4.
29 August 1989 – <a href="Gary%20Pallister">Gary Pallister</a> becomes Britain's most expensive defender in a £2.3 million move from <a href="Middlesbrough%20F.C.">Middlesbrough</a> to Manchester United.
30 August 1989 - Manchester United suffer another disappointing First Division result, losing 2-0 at home to Norwich. Coventry go top of the First Division with a 2-1 home win over Manchester City.
31 August 1989 – The first month of the league season ends with Coventry City as First Division leaders after three wins from four games. Sheffield Wednesday prop up the table, followed by newly promoted Manchester City and Crystal Palace. Defending champions Arsenal occupy a lowly 15th place. The Second Division promotion race gets underway with <a href="West%20Ham%20United%20F.C.">West Ham United</a> leading the table level on points with <a href="Blackburn%20Rovers%20F.C.">Blackburn Rovers</a>. The playoff places are occupied by <a href="Sheffield%20United%20F.C.">Sheffield United</a> (newly promoted), <a href="Ipswich%20Town%20F.C.">Ipswich Town</a>, <a href="Watford%20F.C.">Watford</a> and newly relegated <a href="Newcastle%20United%20F.C.">Newcastle United</a>.
1 September 1989 – <a href="John%20Aldridge">John Aldridge</a> agrees to leave Liverpool after nearly three years to join <a href="Real%20Sociedad">Real Sociedad</a> of Spain for £750,000.
6 September 1989 – <a href="England%20national%20football%20team">England</a> draw 0–0 against <a href="Sweden%20national%20football%20team">Sweden</a> in their fifth World Cup qualifier at Wembley.
9 September 1989 – <a href="Millwall%20F.C.">Millwall</a> beat Coventry City 4–1 at <a href="The%20Old%20Den">The Den</a> to go top of the First Division in only their second season in the top flight. Manchester United lose for third successive game, going down 3-2 to Everton at <a href="Goodison%20Park">Goodison Park</a>. An eight-goal thriller at <a href="Carrow%20Road">Carrow Road</a> sees Norwich and Southampton draw 4-4. In the Second Division, there are a total of nine goals at <a href="Bramall%20Lane">Bramall Lane</a> as Sheffield United beat Brighton 5-4 to go top of the table.
12 September 1989 – Liverpool defeat <a href="Crystal%20Palace%20F.C.">Crystal Palace</a> <a href="Liverpool%209%E2%80%930%20Crystal%20Palace%20%281989%29">9–0</a>, with eight different players scoring, including John Aldridge, in his last appearance for the club.
14 September 1989 – Manchester United sign midfielder <a href="Paul%20Ince">Paul Ince</a> from West Ham United for £1 million.
15 September 1989 – Queens Park Rangers pay £175,000 for <a href="Oxford%20United%20F.C.">Oxford United</a> defender <a href="David%20Bardsley">David Bardsley</a>, with striker <a href="Mark%20Stein%20%28footballer%29">Mark Stein</a> moving to the <a href="Manor%20Ground%2C%20Oxford">Manor Ground</a> in exchange.
16 September 1989 – Ten Swansea City fans receive 16–month prison sentences in <a href="Athens">Athens</a> after being convicted of fighting with <a href="Panathinaikos">Panathinaikos</a> fans after a <a href="UEFA%20Cup%20Winners%27%20Cup">European Cup Winners' Cup</a> tie. <a href="Mark%20Hughes">Mark Hughes</a> scores the season's first hat-trick in the First Division as Manchester United beat Millwall 5-1 at <a href="Old%20Trafford">Old Trafford</a>. Everton go top of the First Division with a 1-0 win over Charlton at <a href="Selhurst%20Park">Selhurst Park</a>.
18 September 1989 – Manchester United sign winger <a href="Danny%20Wallace%20%28footballer%29">Danny Wallace</a> from <a href="Southampton%20F.C.">Southampton</a> for £1.2 million.
23 September 1989 – Manchester City thrash neighbours United 5–1 in the first <a href="Manchester%20derby">Manchester derby</a> since the <a href="1986%E2%80%9387%20in%20English%20football">1986–87 season</a>. Liverpool win 3–1 at <a href="Goodison%20Park">Goodison Park</a> in the <a href="Merseyside%20derby">Merseyside derby</a>, with <a href="Ian%20Rush">Ian Rush</a> scoring twice. In the race to get into the First Division, Sheffield United are top of the Second Division and looking good bets for a second successive promotion, with Blackburn Rovers second in the table and level on points with Newcastle United. <a href="Sunderland%20A.F.C.">Sunderland</a>, Leeds United and <a href="Brighton%20%26amp%3B%20Hove%20Albion%20F.C.">Brighton & Hove Albion</a> complete the top six. <a href="Leicester%20City%20F.C.">Leicester City</a>, often among the pre–season promotion favourites for the last three seasons, prop up the Second Division table sparking fears that they could be relegated to the Third Division for the first time in their history.
30 September 1989 – Liverpool and Chelsea are level on points at the top of the First Division at the end of the month. Sheffield Wednesday, Charlton Athletic and Manchester United languish in the relegation zone.
2 October 1989 – <a href="Cyril%20Knowles">Cyril Knowles</a>, the former Tottenham Hotspur and England left–back, resigns as manager of <a href="Torquay%20United">Torquay United</a>.
3 October 1989 – <a href="Dave%20Smith%20%28footballer%20born%201933%29">Dave Smith</a>, the former <a href="Plymouth%20Argyle">Plymouth Argyle</a> and <a href="Dundee%20F.C.">Dundee F.C.</a> manager, is appointed manager of Torquay United.
11 October 1989 – England draw 0–0 with <a href="Poland%20national%20football%20team">Poland</a> in <a href="Chorz%C3%B3w">Chorzów</a> to secure World Cup qualification.
21 October 1989 – The last two unbeaten records in the First Division end when Liverpool and Norwich City both lose 4–1 away from home, to Southampton and Luton Town respectively. Manchester United record their third league win of the season with a 4-1 win at Coventry. Everton go top with a 3-0 home win over Arsenal.
31 October 1989 – October ends with Liverpool as First Division leaders, one point ahead of Everton with a game in hand. Sheffield United remain top of the Second Division, with Leeds United second and the playoff places occupied by Newcastle United, West Ham United, Sunderland and <a href="Plymouth%20Argyle%20F.C.">Plymouth Argyle</a>.
2 November 1989 – Everton sign winger <a href="Peter%20Beagrie">Peter Beagrie</a> from Stoke City for £750,000.
3 November 1989 – <a href="John%20Sheridan%20%28footballer%29">John Sheridan</a>, who played just once for Nottingham Forest after joining them at the start of the season, is sold to Sheffield Wednesday for £500,000.
4 November 1989 – Chelsea move to the top of the First Division after they beat Millwall 4–0 and Liverpool lose 1–0 at home to Coventry City. Arsenal keep up the pressure by winning a dramatic encounter with Norwich 4-3 at <a href="Arsenal%20Stadium">Highbury</a>. In the Second Division, Swindon boost their hopes of reaching the First Division for the first time by beating struggling Stoke 6-0 at the <a href="County%20Ground%2C%20Swindon">County Ground</a>.
5 November 1989 – Aston Villa record their fifth consecutive League victory with a 6–2 thrashing of Everton at <a href="Villa%20Park">Villa Park</a>.
7 November 1989 – <a href="Mick%20Mills">Mick Mills</a> is sacked after four years as manager of Stoke City, who are winless and bottom of the Second Division. His successor is <a href="Alan%20Ball%2C%20Jr">Alan Ball</a>, the <a href="1966%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1966 World Cup winner</a> and former <a href="Portsmouth%20F.C.">Portsmouth</a> manager.
11 November 1989 - Chelsea remain top of the First Division with a 1-0 win at Everton. Derby climb from 17th to 12th place with a 6-0 win over Manchester City at the <a href="Baseball%20Ground">Baseball Ground</a>. Liverpool's title hopes are dented when they lose 3-2 to QPR at <a href="Loftus%20Road">Loftus Road</a>. In the Second Division, West Bromwich Albion beat Barnsley 7-0 at home.
12 November 1989 - A <a href="Gary%20Pallister">Gary Pallister</a> goal gives Manchester United a 1-0 home win over Nottingham Forest in the First Division.
13 November 1989 – Former England captain <a href="Ray%20Wilkins">Ray Wilkins</a> agrees to join Queens Park Rangers from Glasgow Rangers on a free transfer at the end of this month.
15 November 1989 – <a href="Howard%20Kendall">Howard Kendall</a>, the former Everton manager, is dismissed by Spanish side <a href="Athletic%20Bilbao">Athletic Bilbao</a>.
16 November 1989 – Manchester City sign <a href="Blackburn%20Rovers%20F.C.">Blackburn Rovers</a> defender <a href="Colin%20Hendry">Colin Hendry</a> for £700,000. Three Chelsea fans jailed for hooliganism offences in 1987 are freed after their convictions are quashed by the Court of Appeal.
18 November 1989 - Arsenal go top of the First Division with a 3-0 win over QPR at Highbury. Aston Villa boost their title hopes with a 4-1 home win over Coventry. Manchester United climb to ninth with a 3-1 win at Luton.
21 November 1989 – <a href="Nigel%20Martyn">Nigel Martyn</a>, 23, becomes Britain's first £1 million goalkeeper when he joins Crystal Palace from <a href="Bristol%20Rovers%20F.C.">Bristol Rovers</a>.
25 November 1989 - A nine-goal thriller at <a href="The%20Dell%2C%20Southampton">The Dell</a> sees Southampton beat Luton 6-3, lifting the hosts into fifth place in the First Division. <a href="Ewood%20Park">Ewood Park</a> is also the scene of a nine-goal thriller in the Second Division, with Blackburn beating West Ham 5-4 in a promotion crunch game.
26 November 1989 - Liverpool go top of the First Division on goal difference by beating Arsenal 2-1 at <a href="Anfield">Anfield</a>.
27 November 1989 – Queens Park Rangers player–manager <a href="Trevor%20Francis">Trevor Francis</a> is sacked after just one year in charge.
28 November 1989 – Assistant manager Don Howe succeeds Trevor Francis at Queens Park Rangers.
30 November 1989 – Liverpool, Arsenal, Aston Villa and Chelsea are locked together at the top of the First Division at the end of the month. Manchester City, Queens Park Rangers and Charlton Athletic are level on points at the bottom. <a href="Nigel%20Spackman">Nigel Spackman</a> leaves Queens Park Rangers after nine months to join Rangers.
2 December 1989 - Liverpool remain top of the First Division on goal difference with a 4-1 win over Manchester City at <a href="Maine%20Road">Maine Road</a>, which keeps the hosts at the bottom of the table. Aston Villa keep up the heat with a 2-1 home win over Nottingham Forest, while Chelsea's title bid is hit by a 5-2 home defeat to Wimbledon.
3 December 1989 - Arsenal draw level on points with Liverpool at the top of the First Division when a <a href="Perry%20Groves">Perry Groves</a> goal gives them a 1-0 home win over Manchester United.
5 December 1989 – <a href="Andy%20Thorn%20%28footballer%29">Andy Thorn</a> moves from Newcastle United for Crystal Palace for £650,000.
6 December 1989 – Chelsea bolster their title challenge with a £300,000 move for <a href="Bayern%20Munich">Bayern Munich</a> and <a href="Norway%20national%20football%20team">Norway</a> defender <a href="Erland%20Johnsen">Erland Johnsen</a>. Howard Kendall is confirmed as the new Manchester City manager.
9 December 1989 - Arsenal go top of the First Division with a 1-0 win at Coventry, as Liverpool and Aston Villa draw 1-1 at Anfield. Chelsea's title hopes are further damaged when they lose 4-2 to QPR at <a href="Loftus%20Road">Loftus Road</a>. Manchester United's disappointing league campaign continues with a 2-1 home defeat to Crystal Palace.
10 December 1989 – <a href="Roy%20Wegerle">Roy Wegerle</a>, the <a href="United%20States%20national%20American%20football%20team">American international</a> striker, joins Queens Park Rangers from Luton Town for a club record £1million.
16 December 1989 - Arsenal retain their lead of the First Division with a 3-2 home win over Luton Town, but Liverpool keep up the pressure with a 5-2 win over Chelsea at <a href="Stamford%20Bridge%20%28stadium%29">Stamford Bridge</a>. Aston Villa's title hopes are hit by a 2-0 defeat at Millwall, who are now needing the points to stay clear of the relegation zone after topping the table in September. Manchester United suffer a third successive league defeat, going down 1-0 at home to Tottenham.
19 December 1989 – 18–year–old Trinidadian striker <a href="Dwight%20Yorke">Dwight Yorke</a> signs for Aston Villa.
23 December 1989 - The last league action before Christmas sees Manchester United hold Liverpool to a goalless draw at Anfield, ensuring that Arsenal remain a point ahead at the top of the table with a game in hand.
26 December 1989 - The <a href="Boxing%20Day">Boxing Day</a> action sees Liverpool return to the top of the First Division with a 2-1 win over Sheffield Wednesday at Anfield, as Arsenal lose 1-0 at Southampton. Aston Villa keep up the pressure with a 3-0 win over Manchester United at <a href="Villa%20Park">Villa Park</a>, a result which mounts the pressure on United manager <a href="Alex%20Ferguson">Alex Ferguson</a>, whose team have picked up just two points from their last five games and are now 15th in the league. Norwich's title hopes are hit by a 1-0 defeat at Manchester City, who climb off the bottom of the table. Charlton now prop up the First Division, having lost 3-1 at Wimbledon. In the Second Division, the leading pair of Leeds United and Sheffield United draw 2-2 at <a href="Bramall%20Lane">Bramall Lane</a>. Swindon boost their promotion hopes with a 4-3 home win over promotion rivals Blackburn at the <a href="County%20Ground%2C%20Swindon">County Ground</a>.
28 December 1989 – West Ham United sign midfielder <a href="Ian%20Bishop%20%28footballer%29">Ian Bishop</a> and striker <a href="Trevor%20Morley">Trevor Morley</a> from Manchester City for £500,000 each. Millwall attempt to arrest their dramatic fall down the First Division by playing a club record £800,000 for Derby County striker <a href="Paul%20Goddard%20%28footballer%29">Paul Goddard</a>.
29 December 1989 – Liverpool chairman <a href="John%20Smith%20%28chairman%20of%20Liverpool%20FC%29">John Smith</a> receives a <a href="knighthood">knighthood</a>. Trevor Francis is offered a playing contract with Luton Town.
30 December 1989 - The last matches of the 1980s are played. 20-year-old striker <a href="Mark%20Robins">Mark Robins</a> scores his first goal for Manchester United in a 2-2 draw at Wimbledon, which rescues a point for Alex Ferguson's team but extend their winless run to six matches. Liverpool beat Charlton 1-0 at Anfield to boost their chances of reclaiming the league title from Arsenal, who are leapfrogged into second place by Aston Villa after a 2-1 defeat at <a href="Villa%20Park">Villa Park</a>. There is a six-goal thriller in a Second Division clash at <a href="Boundary%20Park">Boundary Park</a>, where Oldham and Portsmouth draw 3-3.
31 December 1989 – The year and the decade ends with Liverpool as First Division leaders by four points from Aston Villa. Arsenal are a point further adrift. Charlton Athletic prop up the table, behind Luton Town and Sheffield Wednesday, while out–of–form Millwall are out of the relegation zone only on goal difference. Leeds United are top of the Second Division with Sheffield United in second place. Sunderland, Oldham Athletic, Ipswich Town and Newcastle United occupy the playoff zone, while West Ham United's early challenge has fallen away and they now stand 11th in their first season outside the top flight for almost a decade.
1 January 1990 - The new decade begins with Arsenal beating Crystal Palace 4-1 at Highbury cut Liverpool's lead at the top of the First Division, as <a href="Kenny%20Dalglish">Kenny Dalglish's</a> men are held to a 2-2 at the <a href="City%20Ground">City Ground</a> by Nottingham Forest. Title challenge outsiders Southampton win 4-2 at bottom club Charlton. In the Second Division, <a href="Steve%20Bull">Steve Bull</a> scores four goals at Wolves win 4-1 at Newcastle, a result which boosts his side's challenge for a unique third successive promotion, and also drags promotion favourites Newcastle out of the top six. West Ham maintain their hopes of an immediate return to the First Division by beating Barnsley 4-2 at Upton Park.
3 January 1990 – <a href="Ray%20Harford">Ray Harford</a> resigns after two and a half years as manager of Luton Town to be succeeded by his assistant <a href="Jimmy%20Ryan%20%28footballer%20born%201945%29">Jimmy Ryan</a>.
5 January 1990 – Swindon Town chairman <a href="Brian%20Hillier">Brian Hillier</a> and former manager Lou Macari are suspected of making an illegal bet against their own club in an FA Cup tie with Newcastle United in January 1988.
6 January 1990 – Third Division <a href="Northampton%20Town%20F.C.">Northampton Town</a> cause the shock of the <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> third round by beating 1987 winners Coventry City 1–0. Liverpool are held 0–0 by <a href="Swansea%20City%20F.C.">Swansea City</a>.
7 January 1990 – Manchester United beat Nottingham Forest 1–0 at the <a href="City%20Ground">City Ground</a> in the third round of the FA Cup, with Mark Robins scoring the winning goal. The football press had widely tipped manager Alex Ferguson to be sacked if United had been beaten.
9 January 1990 – Liverpool thrash Swansea City 8–0 in their FA Cup third round replay. Second Division leaders Leeds United pay Nottingham Forest £400,000 for striker <a href="Lee%20Chapman">Lee Chapman</a>.
13 January 1990 - Manchester United's winless run in the First Division stretches to eight matches when they lose 2-1 at home to Derby.
17 January 1990 – Derby County replace Paul Goddard with <a href="Mick%20Harford">Mick Harford</a> in a £500,000 move from Luton Town.
19 January 1990 – Arsenal sign defender <a href="Colin%20Pates">Colin Pates</a> from <a href="Brighton%20%26amp%3B%20Hove%20Albion">Brighton & Hove Albion</a> for £500,000.
21 January 1990 – Manchester United are now without a win from their last nine matches in the First Division with a 2–0 defeat at Norwich City, which leaves them just one point and one place above the relegation zone.
22 January 1990 – Almost two months after being sacked as player–manager by Queens Park Rangers, Trevor Francis signs for Sheffield Wednesday.
27 January 1990 – Chelsea are beaten 3–1 by <a href="Bristol%20City%20F.C.">Bristol City</a> in the FA Cup fourth round. <a href="West%20Bromwich%20Albion%20F.C.">West Bromwich Albion</a> beat First Division opposition for the second round running, winning 1–0 against Charlton Athletic. Aston Villa remain in contention for <a href="double%20%28association%20football%29">the double</a> by beating Port Vale 6-0 at Villa Park. Crystal Palace beat Huddersfield Town 4-0.
28 January 1990 - A <a href="Clayton%20Blackmore">Clayton Blackmore</a> goal gives Manchester United a 1-0 win their FA Cup fourth round tie with Hereford at <a href="Edgar%20Street">Edgar Street</a>. Norwich hold Liverpool to a goalless daw at <a href="Carrow%20Road">Carrow Road</a> and Everton beat Sheffield Wednesday 2-1 at Hillsborough.
29 January 1990 – The <a href="Taylor%20Report">Taylor Report</a>, an inquiry into stadium safety following the <a href="Hillsborough%20disaster">Hillsborough disaster</a> nine months ago, recommends that all First and Second Division stadiums are all–seater by 1994 and that the Third and Fourth Divisions follow suit by 1999. Coventry City pay a club record £900,000 for 23–year–old <a href="Dundee%20United">Dundee United</a> and <a href="Scotland%20national%20football%20team">Scotland</a> striker <a href="Kevin%20Gallacher">Kevin Gallacher</a>.
30 January 1990 – In their FA Cup fourth round replay at the <a href="Abbey%20Stadium">Abbey Stadium</a>, Fourth Division <a href="Cambridge%20United">Cambridge United</a> spring a major surprise by beating First Division Millwall 1–0.
31 January 1990 – Queens Park Rangers beat Arsenal 2–0 in an FA Cup fourth round replay. Liverpool end January as First Division leaders on goal difference ahead of Aston Villa, who have a game in hand. Manchester United are still just one place above the relegation zone, occupied by Charlton Athletic, Luton Town and Millwall. The race to get into the First Division is headed by Leeds United and Sheffield United, who are further distancing themselves from the rest of the Second Division. Just two points separate the next five clubs – Swindon Town, Oldham Athletic, Sunderland, Newcastle United and Ipswich Town. Meanwhile, eighth placed <a href="Wolverhampton%20Wanderers%20F.C.">Wolverhampton Wanderers</a> are just two points short of the playoff zone and are looking like reasonable challengers for a unique third successive promotion.
2 February 1990 – Former Liverpool manager <a href="Don%20Welsh">Don Welsh</a> dies aged 78.
3 February 1990 - The <a href="Manchester%20derby">Manchester derby</a> at Old Trafford ends in a 1-1 draw at Old Trafford. Manchester United have now gone 11 league games without a win, and are now 17th in the First Division and just one point above the relegation zone. They would have fallen into the bottom three today had Millwall managed to find a winner at Hillsborough, where they were held to a 1-1 draw by Sheffield Wednesday.
4 February 1990 - <a href="Gary%20Lineker">Gary Lineker</a> scores a hat-trick in Tottenham's 4-0 home win over Norwich in the First Division.
8 February 1990 – West Ham United sign <a href="Czechoslovakia">Czech</a> goalkeeper <a href="Ludek%20Miklosko">Ludek Miklosko</a> from <a href="Ban%C3%ADk%20Ostrava">Baník Ostrava</a> for £300,000. Miklosko, 28, has been capped 31 times by the Czech <a href="Czechoslovakia%20national%20football%20team">national side</a>.
10 February 1990 – Manchester United end their 11–match winless league run with a 2–1 away win over Millwall, who led the league five months ago but have now slipped into the relegation zone. Liverpool are held to their second goalless draw in two weeks by Norwich at Carrow Road. Aston Villa boost their title push with a 1-0 home win over Sheffield Wednesday. In the Second Division, leaders Leeds beat Hull 4-3 at Elland Road.
11 February 1990 - Nottingham Forest move closer to a joint record fourth League Cup triumph by beating Coventry 2-1 in the semi-final first leg at the City Ground.
12 February 1990 – Brian Hillier and Lou Macari are both fined after being found guilty of placing an illegal bet against Swindon Town. Hillier is also given a 6–month ban from football and is forced to resign as the club's chairman.
13 February 1990 – Millwall, still battling relegation despite having led the First Division five months ago, sack manager <a href="John%20Docherty%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201940%29">John Docherty</a> and his assistant <a href="Frank%20McLintock">Frank McLintock</a>.
14 February 1990 – <a href="Oldham%20Athletic%20F.C.">Oldham Athletic</a> defeat West Ham United 6–0 at <a href="Boundary%20Park">Boundary Park</a> in the first leg of their League Cup semi–final, all but guaranteeing their first ever Wembley appearance.
16 February 1990 – Striker <a href="Tony%20Cascarino">Tony Cascarino</a> pledges his future to relegation threatened Millwall despite reports that he is to join Aston Villa or Manchester United.
18 February 1990 – Lou Macari resigns after seven months as manager of West Ham United. Manchester United reach the FA Cup quarter finals with a 3–2 fifth round win at Newcastle United.
21 February 1990 – Aston Villa move to the top of the First Division with a 2–0 away win over Tottenham Hotspur.
23 February 1990 – West Ham United appoint their former player <a href="Billy%20Bonds">Billy Bonds</a> as manager.
24 February 1990 - First Division leaders Aston Villa lose 3-0 at home to Wimbledon.
25 February 1990 – Nottingham Forest reach the League Cup final for the second season running by completing a 2–1 aggregate semi–final victory over Coventry City.
27 February 1990 – Fourth Division Cambridge United reach the FA Cup quarter–finals after a 5–1 second replay victory against Bristol City.
28 February 1990 – Aston Villa finish February as First Division leaders by two points from Liverpool in only their second season following promotion. Charlton Athletic, Millwall and Luton Town occupy the bottom three places, with the two Manchester clubs directly above them. Leeds United and Sheffield United continue to lead the way in the Second Division. Swindon Town, Oldham Athletic, Sunderland and Blackburn Rovers occupy the playoff zone, while <a href="Port%20Vale%20F.C.">Port Vale</a> are emerging as surprise contenders for a playoff place that could be their key to First Division football for the first time in their history.
3 March 1990 - Liverpool return to the top of the First Division with a 1-0 home win over Millwall. Manchester United win at Old Trafford for the first time in four months, beating Luton Town 4-1.
4 March 1990 - Aston Villa miss the chance to return to the summit of the league, losing 2-0 at local rivals Coventry.
7 March 1990 - Oldham reach their first Wembley final despite losing their League Cup semi-final second leg 3-0 at West Ham. Arsenal keep their title hopes alive with a 3-0 home win over Nottingham Forest, and Luton climb out of the bottom three with a 3-2 home win over Coventry.
9 March 1990 – <a href="Middlesbrough%20F.C.">Middlesbrough</a> sack manager <a href="Bruce%20Rioch">Bruce Rioch</a> after four years in charge. Rioch is replaced by his assistant <a href="Colin%20Todd">Colin Todd</a>.
10 March 1990 – Second Division Oldham Athletic reach the FA Cup quarter–finals after defeating Everton 2–1 after extra time in their fifth round second replay. Cambridge United's cup run is ended by Crystal Palace in the sixth round. There is no shortage of league action grabbing the headlines, including a 4-2 win for Coventry away to Nottingham Forest, which lifts the visitors into sixth place. Arsenal's title hopes are dented when they are held to a 1-1 draw by Manchester City at Maine Road. Aston Villa return to the top of the table with a 2-0 home win over Luton.
11 March 1990 – Manchester United achieve a 1–0 FA Cup quarter–final win over <a href="Sheffield%20United%20F.C.">Sheffield United</a> at <a href="Bramall%20Lane">Bramall Lane</a>.
12 March 1990 – Bristol City striker <a href="Dean%20Horrix">Dean Horrix</a>, 28, is killed in a car crash a week after joining the club from Millwall.
14 March 1990 – First Division leaders Aston Villa suffer a shock 3–0 defeat at Oldham Athletic in the FA Cup quarter–finals, while Liverpool's double bid remains on course after a 1–0 replay win over Queens Park Rangers. Nottingham Forest build for the future with an £80,000 move for <a href="Runcorn%20F.C.">Runcorn's</a> 22–year–old Northern Irish winger <a href="Ian%20Woan">Ian Woan</a>.
15 March 1990 – Manchester City sign striker <a href="Niall%20Quinn">Niall Quinn</a> from Arsenal for £700,000.
17 March 1990 - Aston Villa remain top of the table with a 1-0 win at Derby, extending their lead over Liverpool to five points, although the Reds have two games in hand.
18 March 1990 - Liverpool cut the gap at the top of the First Division to two points, and still have a game in hand, after beating Manchester United 2-1 at Old Trafford.
20 March 1990 – <a href="Chester%20City%20F.C.">Chester City</a> are taken over by <a href="Edinburgh">Edinburgh</a> based construction firm <a href="Morrison%20Construction">Morrison Construction</a> in a deal which will see them leave <a href="Sealand%20Road">Sealand Road</a> at the end of this season and move to a <a href="Deva%20Stadium">new stadium</a> in 1992.
25 March 1990 – Chelsea win the <a href="Full%20Members%27%20Cup">Full Members' Cup</a> with a 1–0 win over Middlesbrough in the Wembley final. Having already won the cup in 1986, they are the first team to win it twice.
28 March 1990 – England beat <a href="Brazil%20national%20football%20team">Brazil</a> 1–0 at Wembley with a goal from <a href="Gary%20Lineker">Gary Lineker</a>.
31 March 1990 – Liverpool return to the top of the First Division at the end of the month, leading the table on goal difference with a game in hand ahead of Aston Villa. Millwall are eight points from safety at the bottom, and are joined in the relegation zone by Charlton Athletic and Manchester City. Leeds United and Sheffield United continue to lead the Second Division, with Wolverhampton Wanderers having leapfrogged Sunderland into the playoff zone where they join Swindon Town, Newcastle United and Blackburn Rovers.
1 April 1990 – Millwall's six–week hunt for a new manager ends when they appoint Bruce Rioch.
3 April 1990 - Liverpool return to the top of the First Division with a 2-1 win over Wimbledon at Anfield.
8 April 1990 – Liverpool's hopes of a unique second double are ended when they lose 4–3 after extra time to Crystal Palace in the <a href="FA%20Cup%20semi-finals">semi–finals of the FA Cup</a> at <a href="Villa%20Park">Villa Park</a>. Manchester United draw 3–3 with Oldham Athletic in the other semi–final at <a href="Maine%20Road">Maine Road</a>.
11 April 1990 – Manchester United beat Oldham Athletic 2–1 after extra time in the FA Cup semi–final replay. The game is however marred by controversy after referee <a href="Joe%20Worrall%20%28referee%29">Joe Worrall</a> fails to award Oldham an early goal after <a href="Nick%20Henry">Nick Henry</a>'s shot clearly crosses the line. In the league, Liverpool move closer to their 18th league title with a 4–0 away win over struggling Charlton Athletic, in which on–loan striker <a href="Ronny%20Rosenthal">Ronny Rosenthal</a> scores a hat–trick. Aston Villa keep up their challenge by winning 1–0 away to Arsenal.
14 April 1990 – Millwall are relegated to the Second Division after losing 2–0 at Derby County. Charlton's 3-2 defeat at Southampton leaves them needing to win their four remaining games to stand any chance of avoiding relegation. Liverpool remain top of the table but drop two points when they are held to a 2-2 draw by Nottingham Forest at Anfield.
16 April 1990 - Luton are left needing at least six points from their final three games to avoid relegation after losing 3-0 at Nottingham Forest. Manchester City's survival is confirmed with a 1-0 win at Norwich. There is major drama in the Second Division promotion race, when leaders Leeds beat Sheffield United 4-0 at Elland Road, sending the visitors into third place, as Newcastle move into second place with a 3-0 home win over Stoke, which sends the visitors down to the Third Division.
17 April 1990 – 20–year–old striker <a href="Mark%20Robins">Mark Robins</a> scores twice in Manchester United's 2–0 home league win over Aston Villa – a result which puts the opposition's title hopes into serious doubt. Charlton Athletic lose 2–1 at home to Wimbledon and are relegated.
21 April 1990 - Liverpool take another step towards the title with a 4-1 home win over Chelsea. Aston Villa keep their hopes alive with a 1-0 home win over Millwall. Luton keep their survival bid alive with a 2-0 home win over Arsenal, while Sheffield Wednesday are still in danger of going down with a 1-0 defeat to QPR at <a href="Loftus%20Road">Loftus Road</a>.
28 April 1990 – Liverpool seal their 18th top division title with a 2–1 home win over Queens Park Rangers as Aston Villa draw 3–3 at home to Norwich City. The battle to avoid the last relegation place in the First Division will go right to the wire, with Luton and Sheffield Wednesday both winning their penultimate First Division games. The Second Division promotion race will also go right down to the wire. Newcastle's 2-1 home win over West Ham keeps them in the hunt for automatic promotion, while leaving the visiting side's playoff hopes hanging by a thread. Leeds remain top of the table but second placed Sheffield United will go up and move into pole position if they win their game in hand. <a href="Chester%20City%20F.C.">Chester City</a> play the final <a href="Football%20League">Football League</a> game at their <a href="Sealand%20Road">Sealand Road</a> home of 84 years – a 2–0 win over <a href="Rotherham%20United%20F.C.">Rotherham United</a>.
29 April 1990 – Nottingham Forest retain the League Cup with a 1–0 win over Oldham Athletic in the <a href="1990%20Football%20League%20Cup%20Final">final</a>. <a href="Nigel%20Jemson">Nigel Jemson</a> scores the only goal of the game. Colchester United are relegated to the <a href="National%20League%20%28division%29">GM Vauxhall Conference</a> after 40 years in the <a href="Football%20League">Football League</a>, their demotion from the Fourth Division being confirmed by a 4-0 defeat to <a href="Cambridge%20United%20F.C.">Cambridge United</a> at the <a href="Abbey%20Stadium">Abbey Stadium</a>, a result which keeps the home side's playoff hopes alive.
30 April 1990 – The month ends with Liverpool confirmed as First Division champions, and Aston Villa sure of second place. Luton Town trail Sheffield Wednesday by three points with one game remaining in the fight to avoid the last relegation place. The Second Division promotion race is still wide open. Leeds United (top), Sheffield United (second) and Newcastle United (third) are fighting it out for automatic promotion. Swindon Town, Blackburn Rovers and Sunderland complete the top six, but West Ham United, Wolverhampton Wanderers, Ipswich Town and Oldham Athletic still have a mathematical chance of breaking into the playoffs.
1 May 1990 – Kenny Dalglish makes his final appearance for Liverpool at the age of 39, in their 1–0 home league win over <a href="Derby%20County%20F.C.">Derby County</a>. The only goal of the game comes from <a href="Gary%20Gillespie">Gary Gillespie</a>. Sheffield United miss the chance to seal promotion to the First Division, being held to a goalless draw by Blackburn at <a href="Ewood%20Park">Ewood Park</a>.
5 May 1990 – Sheffield Wednesday are relegated on goal difference behind Luton Town, who win their final game of the season 3–2 at Derby County while the Hillsborough club lose 3–0 at home to Nottingham Forest. Liverpool's season ends in style with a 6–1 away win over Coventry City, and Tottenham Hotspur pip Arsenal to third place by one point. Sheffield United seal promotion back to the First Division after 14 years away. <a href="Dave%20Bassett">Dave Bassett</a> achieves the sixth promotion of his career with a Blades side who finished level on points with champions Leeds United. Leeds United's promotion celebrations are marred when their fans riot in <a href="Bournemouth">Bournemouth</a> in the aftermath of the promotion clinching game against <a href="AFC%20Bournemouth">AFC Bournemouth</a>, who were relegated by the result.
12 May 1990 – Manchester United and Crystal Palace draw 3–3 in the <a href="1990%20FA%20Cup%20Final">FA Cup final</a>, forcing a replay. <a href="Mark%20Hughes">Mark Hughes</a> is on the scoresheet twice for United and <a href="Bryan%20Robson">Bryan Robson</a> once. Substitute <a href="Ian%20Wright">Ian Wright</a> scores two of Palace's goals, the other goal coming from <a href="Gary%20O%27Reilly">Gary O'Reilly</a>.
17 May 1990 – A <a href="Lee%20Martin%20%28defender%29">Lee Martin</a> goal gives Manchester United the FA Cup in a 1–0 replay victory over Crystal Palace.
18 May 1990 – <a href="David%20Seaman">David Seaman</a> becomes Britain's most expensive goalkeeper when he agrees to join Arsenal in a £1.3 million move from Queens Park Rangers.
21 May 1990 – 34 Bolton Wanderers hooligans who were convicted of taking part in attacks on police officers and rival supporters are banned from travelling to Italy for the duration of the World Cup by the Italian government.
19 May 1990 – Chelsea sign Irish midfielder <a href="Andy%20Townsend">Andy Townsend</a> from Norwich City for £1.5 million.
24 May 1990 – <a href="Bobby%20Robson">Bobby Robson</a> announces that he will step down as England manager after the World Cup to take over as manager of <a href="Netherlands">Dutch</a> side <a href="PSV%20Eindhoven">PSV Eindhoven</a>.
28 May 1990 – Swindon Town win the <a href="Football%20League%20Second%20Division">Second Division</a> playoff final by beating <a href="Sunderland%20A.F.C.">Sunderland</a> 1–0, but their place in the <a href="Football%20League%20First%20Division">First Division</a> remains in doubt over the alleged tax scandal, over which Colin Calderwood has now been cleared but Lou Macari, Brian Hillier and Vince Farrar have been charged.
31 May 1990 – Aston Villa chairman <a href="Doug%20Ellis">Doug Ellis</a> gives the Football Association permission to interview manager <a href="Graham%20Taylor%20%28footballer%29">Graham Taylor</a> for the England manager's job. Other names linked to the vacancy included <a href="Howard%20Wilkinson">Howard Wilkinson</a> of Leeds United, Terry Venables of Tottenham Hotspur, <a href="Howard%20Kendall">Howard Kendall</a> of Manchester City and the surprise candidate <a href="Joe%20Royle">Joe Royle</a> of Oldham Athletic, who has yet to manage in the top division.
1 June 1990 – The Football League votes to revert to a 22–club First Division for the 1991–92 season, while the Fourth Division will have 23 clubs in 1991–92 and 24 clubs in 1992–93, with no relegation to the <a href="Football%20Conference">Football Conference</a> for the next two seasons.
2 June 1990 – England struggle to a 1–1 draw against <a href="Tunisia%20national%20football%20team">Tunisia</a> in <a href="Tunis">Tunis</a> in their final World Cup warm–up match.
5 June 1990 – Leeds United prepare for their First Division comeback with a £1million move for Gary McAllister of Leicester City. Three England fans receive 20–day prison sentences imposed by a court in <a href="Sardinia">Sardinia</a> after being found guilty of theft and criminal damage.
6 June 1990 – Manchester United pay Oldham Athletic £625,000 for <a href="Republic%20of%20Ireland">Irish</a> full–back <a href="Denis%20Irwin">Denis Irwin</a>.
7 June 1990 – Swindon Town are found guilty on 34 charges of financial irregularities at a <a href="the%20Football%20League">Football League</a> hearing. They are relegated to the <a href="Football%20League%20Third%20Division">Third Division</a> as a punishment. Wimbledon pay Maidstone United £300,000 for defender <a href="Warren%20Barton">Warren Barton</a>.
11 June 1990 – England open their World Cup campaign with a 1–1 draw against <a href="Republic%20of%20Ireland%20national%20football%20team">Republic of Ireland</a>.
12 June 1990 – Nottingham Forest sign midfielder <a href="Roy%20Keane">Roy Keane</a> (19 in August) from Irish club <a href="Cobh%20Ramblers">Cobh Ramblers</a> for £10,000.
14 June 1990 – Leeds United prepare for their return to the First Division by signing Arsenal goalkeeper <a href="John%20Lukic">John Lukic</a> for £1 million.
16 June 1990 – England draw 0–0 with <a href="Netherlands%20national%20football%20team">the Netherlands</a> in their second World Cup group game, leaving them needing to win the final group game against Egypt in five days to reach the Second Round.
21 June 1990 – England clinch qualification for the World Cup Second Round by beating <a href="Egypt%20national%20football%20team">Egypt</a> 1–0 in their final group game.
26 June 1990 – England reach the quarter–finals of the World Cup with a second round 1–0 victory over <a href="Belgium%20national%20football%20team">Belgium</a>.
29 June 1990 – Liverpool complete the permanent transfer of Israeli striker <a href="Ronny%20Rosenthal">Ronnie Rosenthal</a> from <a href="Standard%20Li%C3%A8ge">Standard Liège</a> for £1 million.
1 July 1990 – England beat <a href="Cameroon%20national%20football%20team">Cameroon</a> 3–2 in the World Cup quarter finals, securing qualification to the semi–finals for the first time since <a href="1966%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">the 1966 tournament</a>.
2 July 1990 – Swindon Town win an appeal against their relegation to the Third Division, but miss out on promotion to the First Division and remain in the Second Division. Their place in the First Division goes to Sunderland.
4 July 1990 – England's hopes of World Cup glory are ended after they lose on penalties to <a href="West%20Germany%20national%20football%20team">West Germany</a> in the semi–finals after a 1–1 draw.
7 July 1990 – England lose 2–1 to host nation <a href="Italy%20national%20football%20team">Italy</a> in the World Cup third place play–off.
FA Cup.
<a href="Alex%20Ferguson">Alex Ferguson</a> silenced the critics who attacked him for a lack of progress in the league by guiding Manchester United to a 1–0 replay victory over <a href="Crystal%20Palace%20F.C.">Crystal Palace</a> in the FA Cup <a href="1990%20FA%20Cup%20Final">final</a>, which was achieved after a 3–3 draw. The pivotal game in his side's season had been in the televised third round tie at <a href="Nottingham%20Forest%20F.C.">Nottingham Forest</a>, when a <a href="Mark%20Robins">Mark Robins</a> goal gave relegation-threatened United a surprise win and triggered improved times for the club. They won the <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> despite not playing a home game along the way, giving Ferguson his first major trophy as United's manager.
The season produced arguably the most memorable combination of <a href="FA%20Cup%20semi-finals">FA Cup semi-finals</a> in history, as <a href="Crystal%20Palace%20F.C.">Crystal Palace</a> surprisingly beat <a href="Liverpool%20F.C.">Liverpool</a> 4–3 just a couple of hours before <a href="Manchester%20United%20F.C.">Manchester United</a> and <a href="Oldham%20Athletic%20A.F.C.">Oldham Athletic</a> fought out a 3–3 draw, with United going on to win the replay 2–1.
Football League Cup.
<a href="Brian%20Clough">Brian Clough</a>'s <a href="Nottingham%20Forest%20F.C.">Nottingham Forest</a> retained their League Cup by beating <a href="Oldham%20Athletic%20F.C.">Oldham Athletic</a> 1–0 at <a href="Wembley%20Stadium%20%281923%29">Wembley</a>.
Football League.
First Division.
<a href="Liverpool%20F.C.">Liverpool</a> secured their 18th First Division title, finishing nine points ahead of <a href="Aston%20Villa%20F.C.">Aston Villa</a>. <a href="Tottenham%20Hotspur%20F.C.">Tottenham Hotspur</a>, defending champions <a href="Arsenal%20F.C.">Arsenal</a> and newly promoted <a href="Chelsea%20F.C.">Chelsea</a> completed the top five.
<a href="Nottingham%20Forest%20F.C.">Nottingham Forest</a> retained the <a href="Football%20League%20Cup">Football League Cup</a> to match the record of four wins in the competition set by Liverpool, while <a href="Manchester%20United%20F.C.">Manchester United</a>, despite experiencing their worst league campaign since returning to the top-flight in 1975, finally won some silverware at the fourth attempt under <a href="Alex%20Ferguson">Alex Ferguson</a> by lifting the <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> to match the record of seven wins in the competition set by Aston Villa and Tottenham Hotspur.
<a href="Millwall%20F.C.">Millwall</a>, who had briefly topped the First Division in September, ended the season relegated in bottom place with a mere five wins to their name all season. <a href="Charlton%20Athletic%20F.C.">Charlton Athletic's</a> luck finally ran out after four seasons as they became the next team to go down. The last relegation place went to <a href="Sheffield%20Wednesday%20F.C.">Sheffield Wednesday</a>, who went down on goal difference after a late escape act by <a href="Luton%20Town%20F.C.">Luton Town</a>.
Second Division.
<a href="Leeds%20United%20A.F.C.">Leeds United</a> finally made it back to the First Division after eight years away by winning the Second Division title. They were joined by <a href="Sheffield%20United%20A.F.C.">Sheffield United</a>, who won a second successive promotion under manager <a href="Dave%20Bassett">Dave Bassett</a>, who won his sixth promotion in 10 seasons. <a href="Swindon%20Town%20F.C.">Swindon Town</a> did beat <a href="Sunderland%20A.F.C.">Sunderland</a> in the playoff final, but their opponents were then promoted instead after Swindon admitted to 36 charges of financial irregularities.
<a href="Stoke%20City%20F.C.">Stoke City's</a> decline continued as they fell into the Third Division, along with a <a href="Bradford%20City%20F.C.">Bradford City</a> side who had almost won promotion to the First Division two years earlier, while <a href="AFC%20Bournemouth">AFC Bournemouth</a>'s late season slump cost them their Second Division status and helped save <a href="Middlesbrough%20F.C.">Middlesbrough</a> from a second successive relegation, as well as keeping <a href="West%20Bromwich%20Albion%20F.C.">West Bromwich</a> clear of Third Division football for the first time.
Third Division.
Former England international <a href="Gerry%20Francis">Gerry Francis</a> guided <a href="Bristol%20Rovers%20F.C.">Bristol Rovers</a> into the Second Division at the third attempt as they won the Third Division title, with local rivals <a href="Bristol%20City%20F.C.">Bristol City</a> joining them as runners-up, and <a href="Neil%20Warnock">Neil Warnock's</a> <a href="Notts%20County%20F.C.">Notts County</a> triumphing in the playoffs.
<a href="Walsall%20F.C.">Walsall</a>, <a href="Blackpool%20F.C.">Blackpool</a>, <a href="Northampton%20Town%20F.C.">Northampton Town</a> and <a href="Cardiff%20City%20F.C.">Cardiff City</a> were all relegated to the Fourth Division.
Fourth Division.
<a href="Exeter%20City%20F.C.">Exeter City</a> were promoted as Fourth Division champions, joined in the automatic promotion places by <a href="Southend%20United%20F.C.">Southend United</a> and a rejuvenated <a href="Grimsby%20Town%20F.C.">Grimsby Town</a> who were on the comeback trail from near closure two years earlier. New manager <a href="John%20Beck%20%28footballer%29">John Beck</a> kicked off his managerial career with playoff glory at <a href="Cambridge%20United%20F.C.">Cambridge United</a>. <a href="Maidstone%20United%20F.C.%20%281897%29">Maidstone United</a> debuted in the Football League and reached the promotion play-offs but lost in the semi-final. <a href="Colchester%20United%20F.C.">Colchester United's</a> 40-year stay in the <a href="Football%20League">Football League</a> ended in relegation.

Non-league football.
The divisional champions of the major non-League competitions were:
